lines.text: [last lines]
I always told you I was very self-reliant.
Kent, our radio program starts next week, and you haven't found me a Little Miss America yet. I'm beginning to lose faith in the whole idea.
Mr. Bartlett, if you'll just be patient...
Patient? Look at all this advertising! I can't understand how you had the nerve to spread publicity from coast to coast before you even found the right child for the program.
Now, just a minute, Mr. Bartlett. You've turned down some pretty talented kids, and some of them were very successful radio entertainers.
That's just what was wrong with them. They weren't what the program calls for, and you know it.
Are you sure you got that song right?
Uncle Harry, I'm awfully hungry.
Not so loud. We'll be eating regular as soon as I hand these guys the old one-two.
The last time you gave someone the old one-two, you came home with a black eye.
What's stage-fright?
Well, it's something you'll never get.
Why not?
Because I trained you, that's why. You're a trouper. That kid's just an amateur.
Sorry, honey, I guess you're not the type.
I can change my type. I'm very self-reliant.
But you didn't even let her finish her song!
The chief said he heard enough, and he's the one giving orders around here.
All right, but you're passing up the most colossal, the most...
You told him that once before, Uncle Harry, and it didn't do any good.
We'd really get further in our act if he wouldn't talk so much.
Is he in the act with you?
I'm the act. He's my manager.
I bet you would make a better manager than your father.
Uncle Harry isn't my father. He's my stepfather. I've been taking care of him ever since my mother died.
Why, you poor child.
I'm not a poor child. I'm very self-reliant. My mother taught me to always be that way.
It wouldn't be long now, Rebecca. Are you getting nervous?
Of course not. I never get nervous. I'm very self-reliant.
Nice of you to show up for the broadcast.
Darling, don't be that way.
I suppose I should cheer when you miss a rehearsal.
Now you know how I feel when you keep me waiting.
Miss Warren, Miss Lee. Miss Lee is an old friend.
How do you do, Miss Lee?
Hello, Miss Warren. I've always wanted to meet a farmer's daughter.
If I had known you were coming, I'd have worn my sunbonnet.
And this is Rebecca, the star of our program.
Oh, isn't she cute? How old are you, little girl?
I'm eight. How old are you?
That's a question you must never ask a lady.
I guess you must be pretty old.
You practically broke my arm when I tried to kiss you.
Couldn't you have at least until they'd gone?
Oh, so that's it. A barnyard romance. No wonder you wanted to broadcast from here. That blonde hayseed has got you doing nip-ups.
Don't start anything, Lola. That kid means a lot to me.
Oh, yeah? Which kid are you talking about?
Land's sakes, that's peculiar. If I didn't know Rebecca was upstairs in bed, I'd swear that was her voice on the radio.
Well, it did sound like Rebecca, but of course it couldn't possibly be.
Homer Busby, get off that bed!
Mirandy! You're talking to me!
Of course I'm talking to you. Now take me to Rebecca.
Oh, Mirandy, I've waited twenty-five years for this moment.
Fiddlesticks.
Don't be stubborn any longer. We're wasting the best years of our lives.
Homer Busby, you're revolting.
Come on, Mirandy, give in.
How can I trust you after the way you've acted?
I swear I'll never keep you waiting again. Give me one more chance.
Are you sure you've gotten all the wild oats out of your system?
Congratulations, you two.
Oh, there's no time for this fol-de-rol. Where is Rebecca? Take me to her!

[listening to the radio]
That was Rebecca!
You're daffy.
I know that kid when I hear her. I've heard her a thousand times.
What would Rebecca be doing on a big radio hookup like that?
I told you when you married me you'd be in the dough, didn't I? Come on, get dressed.
Tony, when I grow up, will you marry me?
Rebecca, I've never received a more flattering proposal, but I'm afraid it won't work out. You see, by the time you're ready to get married, I'll have a long gray beard.
Then will you marry Gwen? She's almost ready.
Young man, what are you going to pay Rebecca?
But Aunt Miranda, I don't want any pay. I love to sing.
Then you don't mind, Miss Wilkins?
Of course I mind. I'm not going to have my niece be a big radio star and not get paid for it.
You won't have a thing to worry about, I assure you.
Aunt Miranda, you're an old dear.
You're a honey, Miss Wilkins.
And how about me?
Homer Busby, you're an old fool.
But you can't wait much longer, Aunt Miranda.
She's right, Mirandy. I got my rig outside if you want to take a little ride in the moonlight.
Go on, I'll bring Rebecca home.
Homer Busby, you always were impulsive.
Gee, that was a swell program, wasn't it?
Yes, it was.
Wasn't she wonderful?
Rebecca's all right.
Oh, yes, she is, but I meant Lola. Gosh, she's sweet.
So it's like that, is it?
Well, only on my side. She's crazy about the chief.
Oh, really?
Gee, he's a lucky guy. He gets everything he wants.
Gwen, when these are done, let's take some over to Tony.
I'll be too busy, but you can take some over to him.
Don't you like Tony any more?
Of course I like Tony.
You sounded like you were mad at him.
Long time no see, folks. Meet the new missus, and this is my attorney, Jake Singer.
Pleased to meet you.
I thought you weren't coming back here, Harry Kipper.
It's like this, Miranda. I've been doing all right, just getting married and all, and I'm ready to take Rebecca back now.
You'll do no such thing! You gave the child up once, and you can't take her back now!
Now, Miranda, there's no reason why we can't be friendly about this.
I'd sooner be friendly with a rattlesnake.
It's obvious that you heard Rebecca on the radio and all you're after is her money.
It's Harry's kid, ain't it? We got more right to her dough than you have.
Oh, Aunt Miranda, don't let them take me away.
Now, honey, you'll have a swell time with me. You can have anything you want.
Then I want to stay here!
Oh, Mr. Kipper, you can't take Rebecca away. She's been happier here on the farm than she's ever been in her whole life.
Now you get out of my house!
Not without the kid, we don't.
Miranda, I don't want to get tough about this, but you're asking for it.
Just try and take her.

Now, my dear madam, all this yelling isn't going to get us any place. Don't forget that Mr. Kipper is the child's stepfather and legal guardian. The courts of New York have decreed that he shall have custody of the child.
Maybe if I work hard, Uncle Harry will let me come down to the farm for a visit.
Of course, darling.
And maybe you and Aunt Miranda can come up to the city and see me too.
You bet we will.
I guess I won't need these in the city. Will you keep them for me for when I come back? Don't cry, Gwen. You said you'd come and see me.
Here are some cookies for you to eat on the way.
Thank you, Aunt Miranda. I'm going to miss your cookies.
And here's a picture of me so you won't forget what I look like. Of course it isn't a very good likeness. It was taken twenty years ago.
I'll never forget you, Aunt Miranda.
Oh, of course you will.
Please, Aunt Miranda, I don't want to leave!
Take good care of yourself, Rebecca.
I will, Aunt Miranda. I'm very self-reliant.
Are you all right, mister?
I'm almost a nervous breakdown. I get this way before every program.
Oh, are you going on the radio now?
That's just what makes me so nervous. I never know.
Then why don't you ask somebody?
They don't know, either.
This is certainly a funny radio station.
My dear young lady, there's nothing funny about it. I'm an organist, one of the best, if I may say so. Hamilton Montmarcy. Perhaps you've heard of me.
I don't think so.
I'm an emergency musician. But there are never any emergencies around here.
Can't I go back to the farm with you and Tony?
I'm afraid not, darling. At least, not for a little while.
But I don't want to stay here.
I know, but you can't always have everything you want right when you want it.
I guess I won't be able to sing for you now, Tony.
Singing isn't important, Rebecca. It's just that we want you with us. But it may take some time, so you have to be a brave little girl.
I will, Tony. I'm very self-reliant.
Well, I guess it's time to go home.
It may interest you to know, Rebecca, that we have no home. Our landlady locked us out this morning.
Why are landladies always doing that to us?
Well, it won't happen again. I'm going to give some of your other relatives a chance to feed you.
Oh, goody! You mean we're going to have dinner?
I mean I'm taking you to your Aunt Miranda's at Sunnybrook Farm. From now on, you're living with her.
But Uncle Harry, I want to stay here and become a success like my mother wanted.
Well, I've done all I can for you. I've taught you everything I know.
I guess it just wasn't enough.
Do you realize if we don't find that kid, Bartlett cancels everything?
Careful, Tony. Remember your apoplexy. I gotta run, darling. Goodbye, Casanova.
Goodbye, Lola.
I gotta hand it to you, Orville. I've been out on a limb before, but I never had a guy behind me sawing it off. You realize we're on the worst spot of the century?
You've got nothing to worry about, chief. We got the kid's address.
You have?
Of course. We got all their addresses.

I'm going up to my farm where I can relax. Birds, trees, new-mown hay, the simple life, that's what I need. Oh, and when you find that kid, be sure to get that contract signed. Pay her anything she wants. Well, within reason. And if you make any mistakes, I'll tear your head off and use it for a doorstop.
Okay, chief, you know me.
Yes, and I'm still regretting it.
Now, you're going to meet your Aunt Miranda.
I wonder if she'll like me.
You be nice to her, and she'll be nice to you.
Uncle Harry, is this where my mother lived when she was a little girl?
Yup.
I think I'm going to like it here.
Now, Miranda, let's not quarrel. I'll only be here a few minutes.
That's long enough for me.
My, this is a fine boarding house.
This is no boarding house, honey.
But I thought everyone took in roomers.
A fine environment you've given her!
I want to have my environment fixed.
I'll wager the child hasn't had a bit of food.
Yes, I have. Uncle Harry bought me a candy bar.
A candy bar? Gwen, take the child into the kitchen and get her something decent to eat.
Oh, I can go myself. I'm very self-reliant.
Well, I'm hungry too, so let's go together.
My name's Rebecca Winstead. What's yours?
Gwen Warren. We're cousins.

I've had Rebecca on my hands for some time now. It's been quite a burden. Of course, I'm only too glad to take care of the child, even though she really isn't my own. But lately, I've had several financial reverses.
What you're trying to tell me is you want me to take the child off your hands.
I'd hardly put it that way, Miranda, but that's the general idea.

You listen to me, Harry Kipper. I'll take Rebecca, but only on one condition. You've got to promise to let me have her for good, so I can give her the right kind of upbringing. I don't want her to come to a bad end like her mother.
Your sister didn't do so bad. You're just against show people.
Show people! If Bess hadn't eloped with that opera singer who died without a cent, she wouldn't have had to marry a no-good like you!
Well, goodbye, Rebecca. Don't miss me too much.
I won't miss you, Uncle Harry.
Well, see you folks in church.
Maybe it's all for the best. He has been an awful trial to me.

[to a piglet]
Oh, you bent your tail. I'm surprised Aunt Miranda lets you wear it curled. I'll bet you haven't had any breakfast. I'll ask Aunt Miranda to get you some eggs and bacon.
What's your hurry?
I was just trying to catch our pig.
Don't you know you're trespassing?
What does that mean?
It means you're very welcome.
Thank you, but I must catch our pig.
I'm glad you're not hurt. Or are you?

[putting his hand over his heart]
I'm afraid so. I've got a strange feeling right here.
I hope it doesn't hurt too much. You better let Gwen and me put you to bed.
That would be a pleasant experience.
I think Homer can handle the situation. I'm sorry we bothered you, Mr...?
Kent. Anthony Kent. I live here, but this is my first trip of the year. I hope you'll bother me again soon.
What does Homer do?
He takes care of Mr. Kent's place.
Why doesn't Aunt Miranda like him?
A long time ago, Homer asked Aunt Miranda to marry him.
Is that why she's mad at him?
Not exactly. You see, he celebrated so much the night before that he forgot to go to the wedding.
Mr. Kent is very nice. Don't you think so?
Come on and help me pick berries.
I'm so glad you dropped in today. I always say neighbors should be neighborly. What do you always say?
I always say that depends on the neighbors.
I can see we're going to get along great.
You did find that kid all right, didn't you?
Well, chief, it's this way. The detectives...
Did you find her?
Don't get excited. There are a lot of other kids.
Quit stalling. What's happened?
Well, chief, I lost Little Miss America.
What? What do you mean you lost her?
It's not our fault. We went to her address, and the kid had gone. I tell you, we even hired detectives. That kid has vanished from the face of the earth.
It's uncanny!
What is, Mr. Kent?
We had a kid all set for our big program. She disappeared, and now it turns out to be Rebecca!
Why, it sounds like a fairy tale.
It is!
I love fairy tales.
My old pal Rebecca! Why didn't you tell me you'd tried out for my program?
I didn't know it was your program. Am I going to be on the radio after all?
You bet you are! You'll be a sensation!
But I don't think Aunt Miranda will like it very much.
Don't you worry about Aunt Miranda. I'll go over there this afternoon and sell her a bill of goods.
Gonna have to be a mighty good salesman, Mr. Kent.
Just a minute, young man. Are you trying to tell me you want to put Rebecca on the radio?
Yes, Miss Wilkins. On a very important program. A nationwide hookup...
Get out of here!
But Miss Wilkins, I don't understand...
Aunt Miranda, please just listen to Mr. Kent.
I want to go on the radio so bad.
This is a very important opportunity for Rebecca. Surely you can't say no.

Oh, can't I? Just listen, Mr. Kent. No! I know what you show people are, a no-good lot! I took Rebecca out of that unwholesome atmosphere, and I'm not going to put her back into it! She's staying on the farm where I can keep an eye on her.
Goodbye, Tony. I wish I could sing to you over the telephone like I did to Mr. Bartlett.
Tony, why not?
What do you mean?
Broadcast from here! It's possible, isn't it?
Yes, it could be done by remote control.
Sure, chief, we could run the wires like we did on the courthouse. Then the kid could stay in the program.
Please let's try it. With all her talent, Rebecca deserves a chance.
Oh, Tony, please do!
It's insane, but I don't see why it won't work. Uh-oh. What about Aunt Miranda?
We won't tell her. You can count on us to keep her in the dark.
